articles.title: About this site
articles.description: The website provides the applications' links and tutorials of the data tools developed by Water Stewarship Team (WST).

articles.title: Tutorial series--Area Comparison
articles.contents:
Pre-treatment
The Waste Rock (WR) comparison tool can automatically detect the ranges of each waste rock category (e.g., cumulative, yearly, etc.).
Step 1: Upload the Base- and Application-Case Waste Rock
Upload the Waste Rock input files for the base case and application case.
Step 2: Select Watershed
Select one of the four watersheds.
Step 3: Enter Categories
Enter the categories of Waste Rock. Note that users must ensure that the selected categories exist in BOTH Waste Rock input files. If one input file does not contain the selected category, the tool will return an error.
Step 4: Enter Percentage
The tool uses percentage to determine whether there is a difference between the base case and application case. If the Waste Rock in the application case was zero while the base case values were non-zero, the percentage would be 100%. The percentage equation is as follows:
\[
                 \frac{WR_{Application~base}-WR_{Base~case}}{WR_{Base~case}}
\]
Step 5: Enter Column Range and Row of RWQM ID
Enter the range of headers in the Waste Rock input file. For example, if the range of headers in the Excel sheet for FRO is A7:AY7, enter “A:AY” for the column range and “7” for the row range.
Step 6: Process, Download Data, and Visualization
Press the “Process Data” button. After processing the tables, users can download the results as a .CSV file. A new section will appear in the sidebar where users can select one category to visualize the processed data. For cumulative Waste Rock, the tool provides an area plot, while the rest of the plots are lollipop plots.

articles.title: Tutorial series--EQuals
articles.contents:
Pre-treatment
The EQuals compilation tool is designed for .xlsx files that are less than 50 MB. If you have a larger dataset, please contact me directly.
Step 1: Upload the Files
In the “Browse” section, upload your EQuals.xlsx file.
Step 2: Select the Fraction
The fraction value is used to compile repeated samples at the same time step that have both “above detection” (i.e., above the detection limit) and “non-detection” (i.e., lower than the detection limit) results. The equation is as follows:
\[
Y_{final~value}=X_{above~detection}+\alpha_{fraction}×X_{non~detection}
\]
Step 3: Select SYS_LOC_CODE (Nodes)
The option for nodes will be auto-generated after uploading your EQuals file. You can select multiple nodes if you need to process more than one node.
Step 4: Select Chemicals (Constituents)
The option for constituents will be auto-generated after uploading your EQuals file. The tool will process the constituents that are in our list. Flows, temperature, etc., will be removed from the options.
Step 5: Select Time Step
The tool provides the option to convert the daily average to weekly, monthly, and yearly averages. If you require custom statistical methods, please contact me.
Step 6: Process the Data
After selecting all the sections above, press the “Process” button to start processing your data.
Step 7: Download the Dataset
This tool allows you to download the processed data. If you press the button, please wait a few minutes for a new window to appear, allowing you to select the download location on your PC, as the backstage is busy processing the data.
Step 8: Visualize the Processed Data
After processing the data, a new section will appear that allows users to visualize the processed data in the tool. Currently, the tool supports one node with multiple constituents.

articles.title: Tutorial series--flow Comparison
articles.contents:
Please edit the flow input before uploading it to the tool. Due to the limited capacity of the server, the tool only supports one realization. If you need a more powerful version, please reach out to me.
Step 1: Pre-treatment
Keep only one sheet in the flow input files. For example, only keep “R01” in both the base case and application case.
Step 2: Upload the Base- and Application-Case Flow Input
Upload the flow input files for the base case and application case.
Step 3: Enter Realization i
If you kept “R01” in the input files, please enter 1. If the value of i is inconsistent with the input file, the tool cannot return the results.
Step 4: Enter Range of Data
Enter the range of data in both Excel sheets.
Step 5: Enter Tolerance
Please enter the comparison tolerance.

articles.title: Online tools
articles.description: We provide the waste rock & areas comparison and EQuals compilation tools. Now, the website is still in buidling. More data tools (e.g., flows comparison, Python GUI control for GoldSim) and related tutorials are coming!
articles.contents:
If you are a new user, please read the tutorial articles by clicking top right tab of tutorials.
EQuals compilation tool (version 2)
Waste rock comparison tool (version 1.1)
Area comparison tool (version 1)
Flow comparison tool (alpha)

articles.title: Tutorial series--Waste Rock Comparison
articles.contents:
Pre-treatment
The Waste Rock (WR) comparison tool can auto-detect the ranges of each waste rock category (e.g., cumulative, yearly, etc.).
Step 1: Upload the Base- and Application-Case Waste Rock
Upload the Waste Rock input files for the base case and application case.
Step 2: Select Watershed
Please select one of the four watersheds.
Step 3: Enter Categories
Please enter the categories of Waste Rock. Note that users must check if there are selected categories in BOTH Waste Rock input files. If one input file does not contain the selected category, the tool will return an error.
Step 4: Enter Percentage
The tool uses percentage to determine whether there is a difference between the base case and application case. Note that if Waste Rock in the application case was zero while the base case values were non-zero, the percentage would be 100%. The percentage equation is as follows:
\[
                 \frac{WR_{Application~base}-WR_{Base~case}}{WR_{Base~case}}
\]
Step 5: Enter Column Range and Row of RWQM ID
Please enter the range of headers in the Waste Rock input file. For example, in FRO, the range of headers in the Excel sheet is A7:AY7. So, enter “A:AY” for the column range and “7” for the row range.
Step 6: Process and Download Data and Visualization
Press the “Process Data” button. After processing the tables, users can download the results as a .CSV file. A new section will appear in the sidebar, where users can select one category to visualize the processed data. For cumulative Waste Rock, the tool provides an area plot, while the rest of the plots are lollipop plots.
